title: Solution for installing on newer macOS
body:
To install on macOS with its messy Command Line Tools (`xcode-select --install`), follow this:

As root, manually edit file `/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/include/c++/v1/cmath`. Substitute the line:

```c++
#include <math.h>
```

with the full path of correct file:

```c++
#include </Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/include/c++/v1/math.h>
```

The files `cmath` and `math.h` are in the same folder, but you need to hardcode its full path due to messy search path order in Apple Command Line Tools (and probably Xcode too).

Then build/install it like this:
```shell
python3 -m pip install --global-option=build_ext --global-option="-L/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/lib" shap
```

Ugly, but this is the only way, until Apple fixes its command line tools.

I'm also using the Python framework that was installed by Apple's Command Line Tools.

My system is a macOS Big Sur 11.3 with Command Line Tools 12.5, which I had to reinstall from https://developer.apple.com/download/more/?=command%20line%20tools
